hedline.hl1: Thespians Raid 7 Seas to Aid A Children's Theater Project

abstract.p: More than 500 actors, set designers, volunteers and friends, many in pirate garb, attend costume ball to benefit 52nd Street Project, which teaches children in Hell's Kitchen to write, direct and perform plays with professional theater people; photo (M)

block.p: THE SETTING -- Yar, matey. More than 500 actors, set designers, volunteers and friends, many in pirate garb, crowded a costume ball at the Puck Building on Monday night to benefit the 52nd Street Project, a group that teaches children as young as 8 in Hell's Kitchen to write, direct and perform plays with professional theater people. After-school classes are held in the project's clubhouse on West 52nd Street, and the plays are performed at theaters in Manhattan. Monday night's entertainment included jerk chicken and a play performed by professional actors and students, followed by limbo dancing.
THE BUZZ -- Isaac Mizrahi, his pirate bandanna clashing slightly with his gray suit, said at the predinner party: ''I just think it's a great cause. I love anything to do with kids. It's great fun.''

Monday night's entertainment included jerk chicken and a play performed by professional actors and students, followed by limbo dancing.
THE BUZZ -- Isaac Mizrahi, his pirate bandanna clashing slightly with his gray suit, said at the predinner party: ''I just think it's a great cause. I love anything to do with kids. It's great fun.''
''There needs to be more fun parties,'' he added.

While Kate McCamy engaged in an impromptu swordfight with a friend, her husband, Kevin Roach, the set designer for the 52nd Street Project, said he had designed a modular set adaptable for ''the moon, the bottom of the ocean'' and just about any other scene.
''I've kind of designed myself out of a job,'' he said.

Selena and Robert Evans, two friends of the theater project, came dressed for serious mayhem. ''She told me what I was wearing,'' said Mr. Evans, an educator who was having trouble with his eye patch and ruffled sleeves.

Ms. Evans is a fashion designer who apparently picked up her multicolored blouse from the House of Blackbeard. ''This is a total surprise to me,'' Mr. Evans said of his outfit. ''I'm just trying to see for the evening.''

Maury Schott, a systems manager, was chatting with Howard Leifman, a human resources consultant. Their costumes were limited mostly to hooks: Mr. Schott's was plastic, Mr. Leifman's aluminum foil. ''Last week it was leftovers,'' Mr. Leifman said.
The actress Frances McDormand, the chairwoman of the 52nd Street project (and a 1997 Oscar winner for ''Fargo''), was wearing a pretty, nonpiratical dress.

''I think we're probably one of the cheapest benefits in the city,'' she said of the $250-a-person event, adding that the group wanted all the friends of the project to be able to afford a big party. ''They deserve one,'' she said.
